    2. Comparing the Input-only model to the Leakage and Inhibition Models

    Yi-Shin Lin1, Corresponding Author1,*

    2022-10-03

    3_leak_v0.Rmd

    The figure compares the activation trajectories amongst three different deterministic models. The third column is the input-only model, where the accumulator receiving a larger input arrives a fixed threshold ( i.e., 2.8) earlier than the other. The constant drift rates, \(dx\), (0.5 vs. 0.35) can be see is shown in the lower corner of the figure and the code below.

    A model comparison without the stochastic influence.

    When input signals are subject to signal attenuation proportion to the activation level, it can be expressed as (page 558 in Usher and McClelland 2001):

    \[ dx_i = [I_i - \lambda x_i] \frac{dt}{\tau} + \xi \sqrt{ \frac{dt}{\tau} } \]

    The drift rate decays with a characteristic decay rate, \(\lambda\), proportional to the accumulated activation at a time step. Without a stochastic perturbation, the leakage models are predictable.

    In summary, when the amount of signal attenuation is proportional to the accumulated activation, the choice probabilities of the stronger input of the two show the same pattern qualitatively as the input-only model.

    The influence of the leakage model is that it decreases the growth of activation by suppressing the drift rate. One can see a clear upper bound in the deterministic model. When the threshold is higher than an upper bound and without the noise component, as in the example of 2.8 threshold, no accumulator will reach the threshold because over time the drift rate will decay to 0. The noise influence renders the accumulators still have good chances to reach a decision. In this case I use double sdv = std::sqrt(dtovertau);. That is, \(\xi\) is a random sample from \(N(0, 1)\) and then I multiply it by sdv, hopefully resulting in a random number from a \(N(0, sdv)\) distribution.

    p.vector <- c(Z = 2.8, t0 = .2, dtovertau = 0.1, dt = 10/1000, kappa = .2)
I <- c(.5, .35)
res0 <- rLeak(n = 1, par = p.vector, I = I, x0 = c(0, 0), 10001,
                      nonlinear = F, random = F, debug = F)

p.vector <- c(Z = 2.4, t0 = .2, dtovertau = 0.1, dt = 10/1000, kappa = .2)
res1 <- rLeak(n = 1, par = p.vector, I = I, x0 = c(0, 0), 10001,
             nonlinear = F, random = F, debug = F)

len0 <- res0@counter[1,1] + 1; len0
len0 <- ifelse(len0 >= 10000, 500, len0)
idx0 <- 1:len0; idx0


len1 <- res1@counter[1,1] + 1; len1
idx1 <- 1:len1
groups <- slotNames(res0)[2:4]; groups
d0 <- NULL
d1 <- NULL
for(i in groups) {
  keyvar <- slot(res0, i)[,,1]
  dtmp <- data.table(x = c(idx0, idx0), 
                     y = c(keyvar[1, idx0], keyvar[2, idx0]),
                     z = rep(c("1", "2"), each = len0))
  dtmp$gp <- i
  d0 <- rbind(d0, dtmp)
  
  keyvar <- slot(res1, i)[,,1]
  dtmp <- data.table(x = c(idx1, idx1), 
                     y = c(keyvar[1, idx1], keyvar[2, idx1]),
                     z = rep(c("1", "2"), each = len1))
  dtmp$gp <- i
  d1 <- rbind(d1, dtmp)
}
d0$Z <- "2.8-Decay"
d1$Z <- "2.4-Decay"


# Input model
p.vector <- c(Z = 2.8, t0 = .2, dtovertau = 0.1, dt = 10/1000)
I <- c(.5, .35)
res2 <- rInput(n = 1, par = p.vector, I = I, x0 = c(0, 0), 10001,
              nonlinear = F, random = F, debug = F)

len2 <- res2@counter[1,1] + 1; len2
idx2 <- 1:len2
groups <- slotNames(res2)[2:3]; groups
d2 <- NULL
for(i in groups) {
  keyvar <- slot(res2, i)[,,1]
  dtmp <- data.table(x = rep(idx2, 2), 
                     y = c(keyvar[1, idx2], keyvar[2, idx2]),
                     z = rep(c("1", "2"), each = len2))
  dtmp$gp <- i
  d2 <- rbind(d2, dtmp)
}

dv <- data.table(y = c(2.4, 2.8, 2.8), 
                 gp = rep("activation", 3),
                 Z = c("2.4-Decay", "2.8-Decay", 
                      "2.8-Input"))
dref <- data.table(y = 2.5, Z = "2.8-Decay", gp = "activation")

d2$Z <- "2.8-Input"
d <- rbind(d0, d1, d2)
d$gp <- factor(d$gp, levels = c("activation", "leak", "dx"))
dv$gp <- factor(dv$gp, levels = c("activation", "leak", "dx"))
dref$gp <- factor(dref$gp, levels = c("activation", "leak", "dx"))
p0 <- ggplot(d) +
  geom_point(aes(x = x, y = y, colour = z)) +
  # geom_line(aes(x = x, y = y, colour = z)) +
  scale_colour_manual(values =  pal) +
  geom_hline(data = dv, aes(yintercept = y)) +
  geom_hline(data = dref, aes(yintercept = y), linetype = "dashed") +
  # coord_cartesian(xlim = c(0, 1000)) +
  xlab("") + ylab("") +
  facet_grid(gp~Z, scale = "free") +
  theme_bw(base_size = 20) +
  theme(legend.position = "none")

png(file = "vignettes/web_only/images/Leak-0.png", width = 800, height = 600)
p0
dev.off()

    Inhibition model

    The inhibition model has this equation:

    \[ dx_i = (I_i - \beta \sum_{i' \neq i} f_{i'} - \lambda x_i ) \frac{dt}{\tau} + \xi_i \sqrt{ \frac{dt}{\tau} } \]

    I omit an additional assumption of self-excitatory input, \(\alpha f_i\), which assumes a neuron feedbacks itself with a excitatory signal.

    The figure shows a pair of functions, one can be described by an inverse negative power function and the other multiplying with \(-1\).

    x <- seq(0, 1, .1)
y1 <- 1/x^(-3)
y2 <- -1/x^(-3)
yl <- range(y1,y2)
plot(x, y1, ylim = yl, type = "l")
lines(x, y2)

    Comparing three models without the stochastic influence.

    A close look at the drift rate shows that , the leakage and the inhibition from the other unit shows that the magnitude of leakage in the inhibition model is minimal, comparing to the inhibition from the other unit. That is, the unit with a larger input exerts stronger inhibition on the other unit.

    Over time, this inhibition signal grows stronger, resulting in its drift rate even going down to negative. This simulation does not apply the non-linear cap on negative activation.

    Comparing three models without the stochastic influence.

    Test

    Comparing three models without the stochastic influence.

    Equation (2)

    The second equation introduces the inhibitory influences exerted by other accumulators on an ego accumulator. The authors first stated that the an inhibitory input from others to an ego accumulator is a weighted sum of the outputs from others accumulators, and then assumed a simplified assumption that the weight from all other units is the same, denoted \(\beta\).

    A elegant way to write this in equation is \(\beta \sum_{i' \neq i} f_{i'}\). This is not what exactly implemented. The equation (2) finally becomes:

    Note on Symbols in Equations

    \[ dx_i = ( \rho_i + \alpha f_i - \beta \sum_{i' \neq i} f_{i'} - \lambda x_i ) \frac{dt}{\tau} + \xi_i \sqrt{ \frac{dt}{\tau} } \] ⚠\(\rho_i\) in equation (2) does not equal to \(I_i\)⚠.

    \(\rho_i\) represents only part of \(I_i\). That is, only \(I^{ext}_i\), an excitatory input from a previous layer. Term 1 (\(\rho\)), term 2 (\(\alpha f_i\)), and term 3 (\(\beta \sum_{i' \neq i} f_{i'}\)) is lumped together into \(I_i\). \(\lambda x_i\) represents leakage of
    the activation.

    Reference

    Usher, M., and J. L. McClelland. 2001. “The Time Course of Perceptual Choice: The Leaky, Competing Accumulator Model.” Psychological Review 108 (3): 550–92. https://doi.org/10.1037/0033-295X.108.3.550.
